completion:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. White

INDICATION FOR OPERATION 71-year-old female who presents with bilateral lung transplant and complication of post-transplant airway complications requiring maintenance requiring endobronchial stents.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Chen

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 15mm) in good position and patent.
Small amount of tan exudative debris overlying RC2 carina minimally overlying edge of stent; minimal granulation tissue.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Mild granulation tissue at the distal end, non-obstructing.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 100 cc of NS, suction returned with 55 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 71-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 3-4 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

prompt: 56yo M bronch. stents check. RML AeroMini 6mm x 15mm - minor stenosis. lingula AeroMini 6mm x 15mm. did bal 55cc return. used cryo and forceps for gran tissue. Dr. Chen attending. plan 31640 31641 codes etc.

The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Ingraham

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 10mm) in good position and patent.
Small amount of tan exudative debris overlying RC2 carina minimally overlying edge of stent; minimal granulation tissue.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Mild granulation tissue at the distal end, non-obstructing.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 45-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 3-4 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Chen

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 10mm) in good position and patent.
Small amount of tan exudative debris overlying RC2 carina minimally overlying edge of stent; minimal granulation tissue.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 6mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Thick secretions adhering to the proximal rim.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 50 cc of NS, suction returned with 40 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 95% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 95% patent. After treatment 95% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 95% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 71-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 10mm) in good position and patent.
Significant exudative debris requiring extensive debridement.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Mild granulation tissue at the distal end, non-obstructing.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 120 cc of NS, suction returned with 55 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 95% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 59-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 15mm) in good position and patent.
Moderate mucous plugging at the proximal edge; mild granulation tissue visible.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Mild granulation tissue at the distal end, non-obstructing.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 120 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 90% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 90% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 90% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 63-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 10mm) in good position and patent.
Small amount of tan exudative debris overlying RC2 carina minimally overlying edge of stent; minimal granulation tissue.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 6mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Thick secretions adhering to the proximal rim.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 120 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 90% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 90% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 90% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN

RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks.

All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.

31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Ingraham

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 15mm) in good position and patent.
Clean stent edges with very minimal tissue overgrowth.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Thick secretions adhering to the proximal rim.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 50 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 95% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 95% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 95% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro

All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Lee

INDICATION FOR OPERATION 67-year-old male who presents with bilateral lung transplant and complication of post-transplant airway complications requiring maintenance requiring endobronchial stents.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Ingraham

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 6mm x 15mm) in good position and patent.
Significant exudative debris requiring extensive debridement.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Thick secretions adhering to the proximal rim.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 100 cc of NS, suction returned with 40 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 95% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 67-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Doe

INDICATION FOR OPERATION 52-year-old male who presents with bilateral lung transplant and complication of recurrent microbial colonization and airway stenosis requiring endobronchial stents.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Miller

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 6mm x 15mm) in good position and patent.
Small amount of tan exudative debris overlying RC2 carina minimally overlying edge of stent; minimal granulation tissue.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Thick secretions adhering to the proximal rim.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 40 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 52-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION 67-year-old male who presents with bilateral lung transplant and complication of anastomosis dehiscence, ischemic lung injury, and bronchial stenosis requiring endobronchial stents.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Ingraham

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 15mm) in good position and patent.
Small amount of tan exudative debris overlying RC2 carina minimally overlying edge of stent; minimal granulation tissue.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 6mm x 10mm) in good position and patent. Thick secretions adhering to the proximal rim.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 60 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 95% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 85% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 67-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.

prompt: Operative note: 74 F, bilat lung txp. Ind: post-transplant airway complications requiring maintenance. Findings: RML stent (AeroMini 8mm x 15mm) with minor stenosis. Lingula (AeroMini 5mm x 10mm) minor stenosis. Interventions: Cryo, debridement, BAL (120/25cc). Plan repeat 3-4 wks. Attending Dr. Bowers.

PROCEDURE
31899 Unlisted Procedure (Trach Change with Mature Tract or Procedure NOS) 
31646 Therapeutic aspiration subsequent episodes 
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing 
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 
31640 Bronchoscopy with excision 
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy) 

NOTE: This patient required a bilateral procedure today when this procedure would typically be unilateral (Modifier 50).

ATTENDING Dr. Chen

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; Disposable Bronchoscope; 1.7mm cryoprobe; bland alligator forceps.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL A timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Sedation was initiated, and mechanical ventilation was initiated via the patient's tracheostomy tube.
The Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope was advanced for airway examination. Endobronchial topical lidocaine was applied to the main carina, right carina 1, and left carina 2.

Initial Airway Examination Findings:

Trachea: Tracheostomy tube in good position; distal 1/3 normal.
Main Carina: Sharp.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: RMSB intact with visible sutures, greatly improved from prior with no evidence of dehiscence.
Moderate stenosis noted at RMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse with therapeutic bronchoscope without touching.

RUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring into RUL.
Bronchus Intermedius: Tan exudative debris and granulation tissue noted along the medial aspect.

RML: Stent (AeroMini 8mm x 10mm) in good position and patent.
Clean stent edges with very minimal tissue overgrowth.
Mild non-obstructing mucus adhered to inside of stent.

RLL: RB6-10 widely patent and healthy.

Left Lung Proximal Airways: LMS anastomosis intact with visible sutures.
Mild stenosis at LMSB anastomosis site due to circumferential fibrous tissue, but able to easily traverse without touching.

LUL: Bronchus in good repair; prior area of full-thickness erosion completely resolved. Small amount of fibrous scarring in LUL.

Lingula: Stent (AeroMini 6mm x 15mm) in good position and patent. Minimal non-obstructing mucus in stent.
Unable to traverse with therapeutic scope due to size, but fully patent LB4/LB5 visualized.

LLL: LB6-10 patent and healthy.

Interventions:

Therapeutic Aspiration: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the distal trachea, RMSB, RUL, BI, RML stent, RLL, LMSB, LUL, lingula stent, and LLL from mucus.
All secretions were suctioned to clear.

Excision/Debridement:
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at RC2 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the RML stent.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris in bronchus intermedius was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps.
Endobronchial lesion of exudative debris at LC1 was excised with mechanical debridement using bland alligator forceps, improving patency of the lingula stent.

Cryotherapy: Endobronchial lesion of granulation tissue at bronchus intermedius, RMSB anastomosis stricture, and left carina 1 was treated with a 1.7mm cryoprobe using numerous 30-second overlapping treatments.

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL): Performed at RML bronchus. Instilled 100 cc of NS, suction returned with 20 cc of NS.

Results:
RML Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Bronchus Intermedius: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.
Lingula Bronchus/Stent: Prior to treatment 80% patent. After treatment 100% patent.

Completion: Therapeutic bronchoscope was removed.
A disposable bronchoscope with unused sterile channel was advanced for BAL. Residual secretions and saline were suctioned to clear.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.
The patient was transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMEN(S)
RML BAL: Cell count, cultures/micro 

IMPRESSION / PLAN
[REDACTED] is a 63-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for airway evaluation and stent check.
All airways continue to greatly improve; areas of mild-to-moderate stenosis noted as described.
RML stent and lingula stent in good position and patent.
Mild tan exudative debris at edges of proximal stent causing minimal obstruction was excised, and areas of granulation tissue were treated with cryoprobe.

Plan: Repeat bronchoscopy in 2-3 weeks.
If airways remain stable, will pursue RML stent holiday (placed [REDACTED]) at that time.
Lingula stent (placed [REDACTED]) may need to remain in place longer to allow durable remodeling.
